questions.question_text: Which administrator type provides more granular options to determine what the administrator can view and modify when creating an administrator account?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
PCNSA Study Guide page 103.

Selected Answer: C
A Role-based administrator allows for more granular control over what an administrator can view and modify

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

The questions is asking about "granular" options, not privileges, this can be understood further in Palo's explanation:

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/manage-firewall-administrators/administrative-role-types
D. the word Granular means more privileges
There is only an answer because of the poverty of the answers provided. That's sad. C is the answer because it is dynamic AND role-based and the answer can't be one without the other.

questions.question_text: Where can you apply URL Filtering policy in a Security policy rule?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct..checked on firewall
Security Policy Rule-> Actions
Profile Setting
Profile Type:Profiles
URL Filtering:none and default

This is a tricky question, because the question doesn't mention the word "profile" so there also an option to configure a custom URL filtering policy under the Service/URL Category tab. Correct me if I'm wrong.

comments.content: Service/URL Category is not an option

discussion.content:
The correct answer is B. 
IEEE 802.1Q is a network standard for VLAN tagging. VLAN is layer II. 
Layer III interfaces, or sub-interfaces are used for routing, and inter-vlan communication (if needed), but L3 interfaces work with L3 IP addressing, not with VLAN Tags.

C, For each Ethernet port configured as a physical Layer 3 interface, you can define additional logical Layer 3 interfaces (subinterfaces). You can create a Layer 3 subinterface for a PPPoE client for IEEE 802.1Q VLAN when your ISP uses an 802.1Q VLAN tag on a PPPoE subinterface.

Selected Answer: C
It's C, VLAN tagging IEEE 802.1Q is possible only in L3 with sub-ints, L2 is not tagging but VLAN untagged.
Layer 2 does not have sub interfaces. Also 802.1Q is how you configure vlan in Layer 3 sub interface

Selected Answer: B
Clearly indicated here:
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClJQCA0

Selected Answer: B
According to

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/network/network-interfaces

Both B and C are possibilities, but my CCNA kneejerk reaction would choose B.
However, since you can do it at layer 3 (for the same money, "everything" layer 3 was more expensive in the past) and layer 2 is more vulnerable... .
TBH this question should have a "choose two" option because neither can be excluded definetively.

comments.content: Forget to add layer 3 would be the more "modern" option ...

discussion.content: I think it's B. Checked on the FW right now. The question says ASSIGNED so when you Add a Layer 2 Subinterface, there is an option at the bottom "Assign Interface to" and have a VLAN field. In a Layer 3 Subinterface doesn't.

Selected Answer: C
I think letter C is the correct answer. See below.
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClRkCAK
I think it is L3 subinterfaces. You can assign VLAN tag to VLAN interface. Subinterfaces in terms of Palo alto are only L3 subinterfaces.

comments.content:
Accordently "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-web-interface-help/network/network-interfaces/layer-3-subinterface#id5604fdd4-bce9-430d-a111-52372ecc194b"
Correct Answer is C.
You can create a Layer 3 subinterface for a PPPoE client for IEEE 802.1Q VLAN

discussion.content: Answer is B
B. https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-web-interface-help/network/network-vlans
The answer is 'B'

Selected Answer: B
B IEEE 802.1Q is a standard for VLAN tagging in Ethernet networks. In Cisco IOS, VLANs are typically assigned to Layer 2 subinterfaces, which are logical interfaces that allow a physical interface to be divided into multiple virtual interfaces. Each Layer 2 subinterface can be assigned a unique VLAN ID, allowing traffic to be separated and managed based on VLAN membership.
